sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Crohn's disease, Remission maintenance: 500 mg ORALLY 3 times daily
  • Tuberculosis: 4 grams ORALLY 3 times daily

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: Tuberculosis: 150 mg/kg/day ORALLY (in divided doses 3 times daily) up to a maximum of 12 grams/day

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: renal impairment: not recommended in patients with severe renal failure

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Tuberculosis
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Crohn's disease, Remission maintenance
  • Ulcerative colitis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to aminosalicylic acid products
  • renal disease, end-stage

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• hepatic insufficiency; may have poor tolerance for the medication
  • hepatotoxicity and jaundice have been reported; monitoring recommended
  • peptic ulcer disease
  • impaired renal function
  • congestive heart failure (sodium salt)
  • duration of therapy longer than 1 month; consider maintenance Vitamin B12 therapy

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• AAP: Drugs that have been associated with significant effects on some nursing infants and should be given to nursing mothers with caution.
  • Micromedex: Infant risk has been demonstrated.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain, Diarrhea, Nausea, Vomiting
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction, Rash with fever (5%)
Serious
  • Hematologic:Thrombocytopenia
  • Hepatic:Hepatotoxicity (up to 21%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Aminosalicylic acid is a bacteriostatic, anti-tuberculosis agent against Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It inhibits folic acid and cell wall synthesis that leads to reduced iron uptake of M. tuberculosis. It is commonly used in multi-drug resistant tuberculosis therapy which aids in inhibiting the onset of bacterial resistance to streptomycin and isoniazid.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Oral: time to peak concentration, 5 h (1.5 h to 24 h)
  • Effect of food: decreases time to peak to 2 h (45 min to 24 h)

sub.title: Distribution
sub.mono:
• Protein binding: approximately 50% to 60%
  • Protein binding: (kwashiorkor), reduced by 50%

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Renal (glomerular filtration): 80%, 50% or more as metabolites
  • Dialyzable: no

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • do not use if packet is swollen or the granules have lost their tan color and have turned dark brown or purple
  • sprinkle granules on apple sauce or yogurt or suspend in tomato, orange juice, grapefruit, grape, cranberry, apple, or fruit-juice containing punches
  • store in refrigerator or freezer; may be stored at room temperature for a short time

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• chest X-ray
  • sputum culture
  • symptomatic improvement
  • liver function tests and symptoms of rash or fever, during first three months of therapy

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
Paser
Oral Powder for Suspension, Extended Release: 4 GM/Packet

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, or thrombocytopenia.
  • Instruct patients to report rash with fever or signs/symptoms of hepatotoxicity, especially during the first 3 months of therapy.
